reviewText: Little House on the Prairie - Season 2The original nine books could never have provided enough material for the nine TV seasons. New stories were created that continued the original characters, as with other TV shows. The real question is: how authentically did they follow the original stories? Some fans of the original books were disappointed by these TV adaptions. Hollywood changes books to condense and simplify them to fit into the allotted time slots and to reach a wider audience. Her books were written in the late 1930s from personal experiences that no historian can match. Laura lost her savings in the Great Depression. An adult who reads Laura's books can see things that a teenager may miss. The economic depression of their era are referenced implicitly. Young Laura would have little knowledge of these problems. An older Laura would have censored events that were not suitable for children's books. Here are the titles of the twenty-two shows.Disc 1.The Richest Man in Walnut Grove.  Four Eyes.Haunted House.  In the Big Inning.Disc 2.The Campout.  The Spring Dance.Remember Me - Part 1.  Remember Me - Part 2.Disc 3.Ebenezer Sprague.  At the End of the Rainbow.The Gift.  His Father's Son.Disc 4.The Talking Machine.  The Pride of Walnut Grove.A Matter of Faith.  The Runaway Caboose.Disc 5.Troublemaker.  The Long Road Home.For My Lady.  Centennial.Disc 6.Soldier's Return.  Going Home.Character Profiles.  The Ingalls Photo Album.  The Quiz.
summary: The Television Series Inspired by the Books

reviewText: Plenty of people have already reviewed these DVD's complaining about the sound quality and other related gripes that are probably valid.  However, I can't give this series any less than 5 stars simply because I'm so thrilled to have them available at last!  Rather than reminisce about my vicarious childhood in Walnut Grove (which no one cares to hear), here are the episodes of Season Two, in case anyone wants to know exactly what they'll be buying.  These episodes were first aired from September 10, 1975 to March 31, 1976.The Richest Man in Walnut GroveFour EyesHaunted HouseIn the Big InningThe CampoutThe Spring DanceRemember Me, Parts 1 & 2Ebenezer SpragueAt the End of the RainbowThe GiftHis Father's SonThe Talking MachineThe Pride of Walnut GroveA Matter of FaithThe Runaway CabooseTroublemakerThe Long Road HomeFor My LadyCentennialSoldier's ReturnGoing Home

reviewText: The whole Little House series is a classic.  And we get some of the classic Little House episodes in season 2.  Probably the best is the two part "Remember Me", in which Charles has to find a home for three orphans whose mom just died.  He finds homes for them, but nobody will take in all three kids (two boys and a girl-  one family wants just the boys- and a lonely woman wants the girl).  At the end, when they are about to go with separate ways, Mr. Edwards pulls a big surprise on everybody.  I am not going to give it away here.  Let's just say it is a very happy ending.  These and other adventures await the Ingalls in season 2!

reviewText: Little House on the Prairie continued its excellence in season two, and while there are still some problems with this set (which I'll get to later) it's still definitely worth purchasing.There are in all twenty one episodes in this set, and they are all excellent. Some of my favorites had to deal with problems with the Ingalls children like in "Four Eyes" where Mary finds out she needs glasses, and the hilarious episode where Laura and her friend find "gold" in "At the End of the Rainbow." In extremely sad episode from season two is "Remember Me" where the Ingalls's neighbor, a widow named Julia Sanderson discovers she does not have long to live and asks Charles to find a good home for her children, in fact this episode is one of the most heartbreaking from the whole series. But don't worry; there are some less serious episode like "In the Big Inning", "The Gift" and "the Spring Dance." But each episode from this season is fantastic, I think Little House is special because every episode is a must have for any collector, they're all absolutely fantastic.We get more of the same (which is a good thing) in the packaging department for season two's collector's edition release, there are some nice photos of Melissa Gilbert and Melissa Anderson, and Michael Landon and the photos for the disc are nice as well. There also is a pamphlet which includes every episode synopsis for season two. We also get more of the same, (which is a bad thing) the only bonus feature is a photo album (not very impressive) a Little House quiz which frankly is a tacky add on and character profiles. Another complaint (although small) is the quality of the picture in season two, it has been improved slightly it still has its problems. But put that aside and this set is a very good buy.Well I've said about all I can say, a little more effort and this set would be fantastic but hey, who wants to miss out on one of the best television series of all time?
summary: Little House on the Prairie - Season Two

reviewText: This review is about the disks of both versions. I have purchased season sets of both versions and they have some disks with people who don't belong on disks. I believe only regulars should be on the disks, meaning The Ingalls family, the townsfolk, the Edward's, and in later seasons the Garveys. And only in seasons where they are on and a regular. One of the disks in this season and version has Jonathan Garvey. Jonathan Garvey is not on until the 1st episode of the 4th season. On the first season of this version has ErnestBorgnine. He was only on 2 episodes and should not have been on a disk. In the other version "fold out" has the same problem too. In Season 4 disks has one for "Toby Noe" who doesn't come until the 5th season and then he still doesn't belong on a disk. The 6th season has one for Reverend Aldens wife who does not belong on a disk. Season 7 and 8 disks are great, only regulars. I don't have Season 9 and the Movies so I can't comment on those. This season's cover doesn't belong. Bandit and Baby Grace don't come until the 4th Season. The people might be rearranged, but it is the same cover as Season 4 "fold out" version. Season 1 of this version's disks everyone is too old for that season. I wish the people who put out both version had paid more attention when deciding which characters to put on the disks and make sure they are the appropriate picture for that season.

reviewText: The first season was more the authentic pioneer experience, as Pa and Ma Ingalls (Michael Landon, Karen Grasse) moved their brood of three daughters from Wisconsin to Kansas and finally Minnesota. There were Indians and hardships of every kind, and the emphasis was on the family’s journey and settlement. The popular series ran for nine seasons, but by Season 2 the plots were already shifting from pioneer-specific storylines to ones that viewers may have seen elsewhere and could actually identify with better.  Mary struggles with wearing glasses, faces the responsibility of buying a gift for the reverend, and becomes a local hero when she qualifies for a state math competition. Laura finds her feud with "frenemy" Nellie Olsen accelerating, and the families are thrown together this season on a camping trip to gather leaves for a school project. The series is well cast, intelligently written, well directed (by Landon), and beautifully filmed. Though there are plenty of melodramatic moments this season, by design, it's still great family entertainment. And on Blu-ray the series looks fabulous!—FamilyHomeTheater.com
summary: Season 2 still connects, and looks great on Blu-ray

reviewText: I've hit an age where I look at specific television shows and movies and think to myself, "How could that have come out so long ago?" The 40th anniversary of "Little House on the Prairie" is celebrated through the release of the second season of the beloved series on Blu-ray for the first time ever. All 22 episodes are fully restored to broadcast length for the "Little House on the Prairie:" Season Two Blu-ray.Season Two of the series is packed full of action, excitement, drama, suspense, and humor. Charles Ingalls is forced to take on different jobs to pay off his debt. His entire family shows their support by helping to earn the money they need. Meanwhile, Mary becomes the talk of the town as she reveals her mathematical gift. A sick widow taking care of three children catches Charles' eye and he rushes to her rescue. The nation's centennial is cause for a great celebration and the Ingalls hit the town to show their patriotism.The deluxe remastered edition of the "Little House on the Prairie:" Season Two Blu-ray is presented in 1080p High Definition with English 2.0 DTS-HD Master Audio. The picture is fully restored and looks better than it ever has before. It also includes Spanish and French 2.0 Dolby Digital Audio and English SDH.The Blu-ray release of "Little House on the Prairie:" Season Two doesn't have much in the way of bonus material. A 15-minute featurette entitled "The 'Little House' Phenomenon Part Two - In the Beginning" continues where the last edition left off on the Season One Blu-ray. It includes interviews with the children of Ed Friendly and Michael Landon.The "Little House on the Prairie:" Season Two Blu-ray will thrill families looking for something wholesome and exciting to watch together. There aren't very many shows coming out anymore that cater to parents and their children sitting down together to enjoy a relaxing night of television. "Little House on the Prairie" can definitely help fill that gap.
summary: Ingalls overcome hardships in hi-def Season 2 of 'Little House on the Prairie'

reviewText: Little House on the Prairie remains one of my favorite shows to this day.  It is a wonderful series for children and adults alike.  I'm so glad they are on DVD to share with my children.  This is a 6 disc set that includes:Disc 1THE RICHEST MAN IN WALNUT GROVE: After the mill closes, Charles is unable to pay off his debt at the mercantile.  He must take on several jobs at once.  Mary goes to work to help the family, while Laura does extra chores at home.  When the bill finally gets paid, Nels tells Charles that with a loving family like his, he is certainly the richest man in Walnut Grove.FOUR EYES: Mary is beginning to have difficulty at school because she can't read the blackboard.  She really likes her new glasses until the other children tease her about wearing them.  She arranges to lose them hoping she won't have to wear them anymore, but changes her mind when she realizes that her teacher, who also wears glasses, has a boyfriend.HAUNTED HOUSE: Nellie dares Laura to enter a haunted house.  Once inside, Laura meets Mr. Pike the owner, who tells her he is waiting for his wife to return.  Laura learns that she passed away several years before.  The two become friends as Laura helps Mr. Pike deal with his loss.IN THE BIG INNING: It's time for baseball!  After losing badly the previous year, all of Walnut Grove expects to win the upcoming game thanks to their star pitcher, Mr. Mumford.  The population is so confident, that they even place bets on the game.  It looks like their hopes will be dashed when Mrs. Mumford refuses to permit her husband to play because she does not approve of gambling.  Caorline saves the day by suggesting that any money raised from the game be donated to the church.Disc 2THE CAMPOUT: Mrs. Oleson wants to prevent the Ingalls children from outdoing her children on a leaf-gathering pfoject, thus her family accompanies the Ingalls on their camping trip.  The Oleson's manage to get into trouble out in the woods, causing all the campers to have a misearable time.THE SPRING DANCE: Laura and Grace Snider are both trying very hard to get asked to the spring dance.  Unfortunately, the young men they are interested in don't seem to want to go.  The girls decide to take matters into their own hands and simply invite the boys.REMEMBER ME (2 Parts)The Ingalls' neighbor, the widow Julia Sanderson (played by Patricia Neal), discovers that she does not have long to live and asks Charles to find a good home for her three children.  After Julia passes away, Charles has difficulty finding someone who will take all three of them.  Just as he reluctantly decides that he must separate the children, Mr. Edwards and Grace get married and adopt the three orphans.Disc 3EBENEZER SPRAGUE: Charles and Hansen build a bank in Walnut Grove.  The banker is Mr. Sprague, a cold and heartless man.  Not realizing who he is, Laura becomes friends with him.  Suspicious, the banker accuses Laura of acting on behalf of her father who must certainly want a loan.AT THE END OF THE RAINBOW: While fishing, Laura and a friend stumble upon some "gold".  They spend several weeks trying to pull all of the gold from the stream.  It is only when they bring it to the bank, that they learn it is fool's gold.THE GIFT: The school children have saved up their money to buy the Reverend a birthday present.  They give the money to Mary, who is in charge of purchasing just the right gift.  Laura convinces Mary to buy something that they could sell to people with the hope that they could buy Reverend Alden an even better gift.  The plan backfires when they are unable to sell anything.  Mary and Laura explain to the Reverend what they did.  On Sunday, Reverend Alden thanks the children for buying a wooden box that he could put his old Bible in.HIS FATHER'S SON: Mr. and Mrs. Edwards adopt John Anderson.  John is a lot more interested in books than farming or hunting.  Mr. Edwars would like him to consider other activities and buys him a gun for his birthday.  John doesn't want to hurt Mr. Edward's feelings, so he writes him a letter explaining his reasons for not wanting to hunt.  When he gets no response, John assumes that Mr. Edwards doesn't love him.  While on a hunting trip, Isaiah is hurt when John freezes and is unable to shoot a bear.  It is only after this incident that John learns the real reason Isaiah did not discuss his letter.Disc 4THE TALKING MACHINE: Both Laura and Nellie are interested in Jason, a young man who is fascinated by new inventions and electricity.  Laura invites Jason to dinner causing Nellie to become terribly jealous.  Wanting to get even, Nellie encourages Laura to talk about her feelings for Jason while Willie secretly records their conversation.  At school, Nellie plays the recording for the whole class causing Laura to run out dreadfully embarrassed.  It all ends well when Jason admits that he shares the same feelings.THE PRIDE OF WALNUT GROVE: Mary is excited when she is invited to participate in a state-wide math competition.  Unfortunately, Charles can't afford to send her.  The town coudncil decides to pay her expenses since she would be representing all of Walnut Grove.  Mary is terribly disappointed when she finishes second, feeling certain that she has let everyone down, that is until she returns home. . .A MATTER OF FAITH: Charles and his girls leave on a trip.  Caroline, who stays behind, scratches her leg on a rusty nail and doesn't realize until later that she has developed a serious infection.  All alone, and getting weaker by the hour, she must cauterize the wound to save herself.THE RUNAWAY CABOOSE: Mary, Laura and Mr. Edwards' adopted son, Carl, accompany Charles and Mr. Edwards to the train station.  The three children wantder into a caboose that detaches itself from the train and moves backwards along the track.  Charles prevents a tragedy when he stops a train that is on a collision course with the caboose.Disc 5TROUBLEMAKER: The school board of Walnut Grove decides to replace the schoolteacher, Miss Beadle, when it becomes apparent she is unable to control some of her students.  The new teacher, Hannibal Applewood, has a terrible temper.  He develops an immediate disliking for Laura which he demonstrates by punishing her unfairly.  When Charles is made aware of the situation, a school board meeting is called and they agree to reinstate Ms. Beadle.  The children work together to ensure that a particular "troublemaker" behaves in the future.THE LONG ROAD HOME: Charles, Mr. Edwards, and two other men accept a job that involves handling and transporting explosives. They face many dangerous and difficult challenges along the way.FOR MY LADY: Charles is fefinishing the woodwork on the Thurman home in exchange for a nice set of china that he intends to give to Caroline as a surprise gift.  It doesn't help that the Widow Thurman is a beautiful young lady, because to keep his secret Charles must lie to everyone.  When he tells the girls and Caroline different stories, they begin to suspect he is having an affair.  Evertyhing falls into place when Charles finally gives Caroline the china.CENTENNIAL: Independence Day celebrations in Walnut Grove are threatened when the townspeople receive news of a tax ncrease.  A Russian immigrant, unable to keep his land due to the additional taxes, explains that even with the trouble he now faces, he still believes America is a wonderful country.  He reminds everyone that they still live in the greatest country in the world.Disc 6SOLDIER'S RETURN: Mrs. Whipple's son returns to Walnut Grove after serving in the Civil War.  This episode deals with the difficult subject of drug abuse as the young man dies from his addiction to morphine.GOING HOME: After a tornado ruins his crop, a discouraged Charles decides to sell his land and return to the big woods of Wisconsin without consulting his family.  During the preparation to move, Mary and John Junior share their first kiss.  Before they leave, the Ingalls remenisce about the good times in Walnut Grove and finally decide to stay and give things another try.Special Features:Interactive Full Motion MenuCharacter ProfilesThe Ingalls Photo AlbumThe "Little House" Episode Quiz
Title: N/A

reviewText: Season 2 of "Little House on the Prairie" has always been one of my very favorites of the entire series because it includes so many heartfelt episodes that your entire family can appreciate. All of the actors, from the show's producer/director/star, Michael Landon to Melissa Gilbert (who played the lead role, Laura Ingalls Wilder, based on her children's books) are exceptional.Included in this set is a total of 6 discs which includes a total of 22 eps. And this is in digipack which I personally prefer just because it looks nicer and is easer to get in an out of. In keeping with the spirit of the series, all of the shows have a wonderful message that are timeless and life affirming. One of my favorite eps is "Troublemaker." In this show, Laura becomes the target of a ruthless new teacher, hired to take over for Miss Beadle. So, as usual, it's Charles to the rescue, once again.In season 6 Melissa Anderson really started to become a breakout star. Mary was the complete opposite to Laura, but so many people could relate to her because Ms. Anderson was able to put so much life and vitality into this role. And I feel that it was certainly a prelude to future seasons when so much tragedy and drama struck poor Mary."Little House" was recently pulled off Hallmark to make room for Martha Stewart's 7-hour a day daily-marathons which left a lot of longtime viewers of this classic, wholesome, family-friendly series very disappointed because no other show on TV currently captures the magic that "Little House" always did. If you feel like me I recommend getting these DVDs. It's a great way to reintroduce yourself to this classic show.Michael Landon set such high standards and goals that no other television program has every been able to match the type of sentiment and emotion that "Little House" always attained. It is television gold.
summary: the bedrock of which all television should be judged by

reviewText: Once again Lionsgate comes through for LHOTP fans with this new release. This is NOT the same pitiful DVD collection that fans put up with for years. This is remastering the way it was meant to be done. The opening theme has been restored (it was left out the other time) and from what I've watched, the episodes are back to their normal length.  Outside scenes especially look very vivid and fresh as though they were filmed just yesterday. Even far away shots aren't as grainy and unclear as they were the other times I've watched them. As a side note, I just compared the remastered version to the original DVDs. There is NO comparison. Volume is terrific and even with its basic 2.0 sound, the music and dialog come through quite easily. As far as the casing is concerned, I doubt you'll need to worry about any scratched discs as they are all firmly attached to their cradles.Many (including myself) put up with the inferior previous release with little hope of actually watching this classic the way it was meant to be watched. I can say with conviction that this is no longer the case. The only thing I would have liked better is if they included more bonus features. But even then, just having the show look this great is in many ways a bonus enough.Buy this collection. Ignore the fact that you invested a couple hundred dollars with the previous releases. Do it again. You won't regret it.Michael Landon would be proud.

reviewText: I'm extremely please at the quality of this set. It's been an awesome experience to watch these with my daughters on lazy Sundays. My oldest daughter (currently age 12) and I have been reading the Little House series books since she was a baby. We started with the board books and moved through the various versions until we started the chapter books. We're still reading the chapter books but she's finally outgrowing them (Harry Potter moved in a few years ago and more recently it was The Hunger Games series, and the list will go on). We still read from the books but it's been nice to finally introduce the television series that I grew up with to her. I now have a 10 month old baby girl and I'm already reading the Little House board books to her so it will be fun to start the experience all over again. I'm loving the Blu-Rays. The quality is incredible and the price is hard to beat! We pre-ordered ours and paid $17.96 here on Amazon. How could you go wrong? (In comparison I've been paying anywhere between $40-$65 per season for the Doctor Who blu-ray sets!) This review is for season one and two. I'm hoping (praying!) for the studio to release the remaining seasons. I'm urging the fans to go out and buy the sets so we can send a message to the studio that we want the remastered product and are willing to pay for it. It's great having the UltraViolet option as well since I don't have a Blu-Ray player in my bedroom. I watch them through my Roku box via Vudu. It's awesome all the way around!
summary: Season 2 - Thanks again for the incredible remaster and pricing on this awesome family television series!

reviewText: I love Little House on the Prairie!!  I have been watching it since I was a little girl, and now to be able to have them on blu-ray is awesome.  But the best part is how amazing they look!!!  The care that they took restoring these is evident....just gorgeous!

reviewText: Lionsgate has done another fantastic job with the season two blu-ray release of LHOTP.  Like the season one blu-ray set, this set looks incredible and is a vast improvement over the original dvd set. The show is presented over 5 discs in its original 1:37 full frame format. All of the episodes run 48-49 minutes long and all appear to be uncut and are not time compressed.The audio (English, Spanish, and French 2.0) is also an improvement. By no means would I use this to demonstrate my new sound system but the audio is clear and the pitch of the actors' voices are correct as the episodes are no longer sped up as in the previous dvd set. Amazon's product description states there are French and Spanish subtitles. This is not correct. The blu-ray and new dvd set only have English subtitles.I highly recommend this set and looking forward to Season 3. I hope Lionsgate releases all the LHOTP seasons with this much care. If you own the previous dvds and are on the fence about double-dipping with this one, trust me, sell the old set and buy this. This is one double-dip that is really worth it.
summary: If I had a remembrance book, I would surely write about the day LHOTP came to Blu-ray.
Title: N/A

reviewText: By now, into their second season, Little House was hitting its stride.  Some of the show's most classic episodes are featured here in this set, including "The Richest Man in Walnut Grove", showing the Ingalls family all pulling together in order to pay off their debt at Oleson's Mercantile (and showing Mrs. Oleson at her witchy best!); "Four Eyes", the episode in which Mary gets her first pair of eyeglasses; "The Campout", in which the Oleson family invites themselves on the Ingalls' camping trip and not only do Laura and Nellie go down the rapids, but Nellie, Willie and Mrs. Oleson end up with poison ivy; "Remember Me", in which Mr. Edwards not only marries the Widow Snyder, but adopts the deceased Mrs. Sanderson's three children; "Ebeneezer Sprague", where Walnut Grove gets its first (and only) bank; "The Talking Machine", where nasty Nellie Oleson embarrasses Laura in front of her crush, Jason; "A Matter of Faith", the episode in which Caroline nearly dies from an infection while Charles and the girls are on an overnight trip; "Troublemaker", where Miss Beadle is replaced by the stern Mr. Applewood, who has it in for Laura; "For My Lady" in which Charles tells a few white lies to Caroline in order to buy her some fancy new china (and the only episode where Caroline seriously believes that Charles may be cheating!); "Centennial", where Walnut Grove celebrates and the Ingalls and Olesons are pitted against each other in many competitions; "Soldier's Return", dealing with morphine addiction; and "Going Home", where a tornado touches down in Walnut Grove and destroys the first of several of the Ingalls' crops and Charles makes plans to take his family back home to Wisconsin.This series just does not disappoint.  It's a feel good show, appropriate for the entire family, and reminds me pleasantly of my childhood.  It also sends out worthy messages of family importance, loving your neighbor, working hard at whatever you do without sounding preachy.Definitely worthy to add to your collection!

reviewText: I am so glad these episodes are finally on DVD! I grew up watching this series first-run, so I remember scenes and lines of dialogue that are cut out when they're shown in syndication. It's like watching a brand-new show to watch these uncut episodes, because I've had to watch them in syndication for so long! I think they are just great; it's nice to re-visit my childhood this way!
summary: Finally, Uncut After All These Years!

reviewText: Following the March, 2014 release of "Little House on the Prairie-Season 1" now comes word that in May, 2014 "Little House on the Prairie-Season 2" will be hitting stores. This is great news for fans of the series who usually have to wait 6 months to a year for multiple season releases of their favorite TV shows.Like the Season 1 release the Blu-ray edition of "Little House-Season 2" will be the original network prints remastered to pristine condition and shown for the first time since the 1970's when they originally aired on NBC. The DVD's of the series were the paltry syndicated versions where as much as 10 minutes were cut from the episodes.In all 22 episodes will be available along with several bonus features including cast interviews!Season 2 of "Little House on the Prairie" did not finish in the Top 30 programs, but NBC would move the series to Monday nights for the 1976-1977 season where it became a Top 10 hit.
summary: "The Blu-ray's Are Coming At A Fast Pace!!"

reviewText: The second season to this wonderful show. The writing and acting have noticeably improved since the first series.There is a compelling charm to this second season that is particularly endearing which makes it my favourite of all seasons of LHOTP.One of my fave episodes which I often re-watch is 'Ebenezer Sprague' - the interaction between Laura and Walnut Grove's new banker is absolutely delightful.The picture and sound quality is dodgy at times, but overall it's pretty good considering no remastering was done to the original tapes.LHOTP is a welcome alternative to the bucket loads of sleazy, violent and brain-dead rubbish that studios are churning out these days. A classic series that will be enjoyed by all the family.
